The workload at IMRE depends on your team and your project, and my team has a pretty evenly distributed workload, so the staff members aren't over-encumbered by work. One does get a fair few opportunities to write grant proposals to further one's career, and with a supportive manager and a significant project idea, the sky is the limit!

I guess what I am trying to reinforce is that one's experience will be down to one's manager.
cons:
Wages haven't kept pace with the industry or even the inflation rate in Singapore. I think most of the junior staff wages have declined over the last few years as compared to a few years due to the inflation.

Lab space is a luxury, and you have to fight tooth and nail to find space to park your equipment.

A key irritant is the lack of desk space for staff. It's a shame that even scientific staff have to share desk space or are cramped in areas not complementary to the appointment.

Depending on your immediate reporting officer and the research group, these are my positive impressions on ARTC (A*STAR) :

1. CEO David Low is extremely charismatic and approachable. He has a good vision and cares a lot about the employee's welfare. This is in stark contrast to mid-level management.

cons:

1. Toxicity and bullying. Reporting officers hold too much power and have zero accountability. Bullying, yelling at lower level Employees and Interns are quite common. 
2. Bosses generally overwork their subordinates and claim credits. 
3. No growth for women engineers/scientists and ignored for promotions. Group managers / Directors are all males. 
4. Too much buzzword (5G, AI, IoT, Deep Learning) and little accomplishments. Many projects are actually "Old wine in new bottle" and very little novelty. Managers typically overpromise in projects and under-deliver as they never consult the employees who actually do the real work. Blame is almost always shifted to subordinates.
5. Too much attrition and high turnover due to politics and toxicity. Many engineers and scientists jump ship in the first chance they get, as ARTC mid-level managers do not reward hard work.
6. Managers and Scientists delegate all the work to FYPs / Interns and overwork them.

pros: If you don't have the technical skills to get ahead, fret not. Simply find the right camp to join, and do what they do. It isn't about science, it is about which camp gets the support and funding.
cons:
Well. Here are some of the reasons people left:
1) Current ED, Alfred Huan, will spend more time and effort ruining careers than actually helping the institutes maintain a healthy financial situation. Also proven in IHPC when he was there. In fact, someone warned me about him.
2) Poor career progression. If you are in the wrong camp, there is no hope. Corroborated by someone else's comment about sycophants.
3) Burning money on projects that have no immediate or future value. This happens when there are no incentives to push researchers and decision makers to produce results.
4) The inherent culture of outsourcing. Project grants are written about technical abilities that do not exist, for outsourcing later on when grants are disbursed, either through new hires or external "collaborators". There is no incentive to minimize costs and maximize impact by creating capabilities within.
5) Questionable practices. Machines that cost 6 figure sums to repair are not operated by qualified users, while managers claim that there are insufficient funds to support low cost projects. The grant approval process is subject to abuse due to potential conflict of interests.
6) You could be working hard in the lab to help the company and other colleagues, but the toxic rumors will get to you, even if you do not socialize with others. Call it a side effect of a transformation.
7) Every project is expensive when you have one person on the team who can deliver, and 5 others who are there because they belong to the same camp.
